15.author: IMissWinning
15.body:
>Why would we include someone who doesn’t do the things we aim to measure just because he’s out on the field lol

"Doesn't do."  There's tens of reasons why teams can have lower offensive numbers. Teams with worse defenses will have less TOP because they can't get the ball back. Situational football will change a lot of data. These numbers don't exist in a vacuum. 

Why **wouldn't you** include every majority passer in the data set? What do you have to lose by that? If you wanted to weight it you should be doing pass play % or something that better compares across sample size differences. 

Examining inequalities is hard. More data isn't bad, especially when your question is as simple as measuring statistically provable data to composite it. 10 games is a big enough sample size where if someone is top 5, it's very very unlikely that it's an accident. 

If someone is starting 15 games, your should really be adjusting your threshold to accept that. Even if they better passed, you still want to compare their passing when they did throw. 

If you wanted to go with your query, picking a fixed standard would be a fine cutoff. "top 25% of the league by pass attempts per game started" or top 50%. There's better ways to do it than "I  looked at drop backs and I stopped when I saw names that aren't important to me"

15.author: genewolfepeace
15.body: I disagree, this was supposed to be a measure of quarterback play in plays where they quarterbacked, so the threshold should reflect that and did but I ducked up with Lamar

15.author: IMissWinning
15.body:
>this was supposed to be a measure of quarterback play in plays where they quarterbacked, so the threshold should reflect that

You mean where they attempted to throw? You're talking about passing statistics, not quarterbacking statistics.

And again, if you just want to know how well they passed when they were passing, then there really shouldn't be much of a qualifier at all. You're either measuring them at a certain volume, or you are measuring their efficiency when they did pass. 

You're outright ignoring efficiency and saying it's a volume criteria, but your criteria has several basic biases in it that don't even account for team play style, or things like Jacoby having a fixed time window where he can play regardless of how good his performance is, or that it was 3/4 of the year. 

That's just wild to me.

19.author: Ohnah-bro
19.body:
This is the absolute saltiest way to interpret what I’m saying.  My argument is that “if a rule is broken, there should be a penalty”.  That’s it.  I understand that sometimes calls get missed.  I’m also not trying to make a penalty out of something that wasn’t there.  It’s plain from the video in the OP.  You can count the men yourself.

Logically, here’s how you can get there:

Eagles had 6 men on the line.  A valid formation requires 7 men on the line, therefore the eagles formation was invalid.    If it is invalid, it’s a penalty.  If it’s a penalty and it’s accepted, the penalty yardage is assessed and the down is replayed.

Sometimes calls get missed and they don’t have a large impact.  This one happened to have a very large impact.  It was still a penalty, and penalties should be called.

🤷‍♂️

I never said otherwise. The point that you’re missing is that it ultimately wouldn’t hurt the Raiders at all. Worst case scenario (and most likely scenario) nothing changes, and Carr gets cut. But maybe a team is stupid enough to agree to a trade that Carr likes. Certainly doesn’t hurt to give Carr the option to search, because there aren’t any scenarios where the Raiders lose out.

You’ve said before that the major downside would be that the Raiders “show their hand” with the Carr situation and let another team get a “head start”. Do you really think that would somehow shake up the league’s evaluation of the available QBs? I promise you, teams aren’t exactly waiting in bated breath for the Carr situation to be resolved. Two weeks of additional prep, after a full college season of scouting, are not going to shake things up much at all, especially since the team that signs Carr will probably still be scouting QBs anyway. The supposed downside for the Raiders is nonexistent, and the upside of lucking into a draft pick is absolutely worth it in my opinion, even if the chances of that happening are slim to none. Not to mention it helps end your relationship with Carr on a slightly better note, even if it ultimately doesn’t amount to much of anything.

37.body:
> The Raiders are a qb needy team. It is not in their best interest to let other qb needy teams get a head start.

Literal nobody thinks that the Raiders are keeping Carr. Every single team in the league will consider them QB-needy. This “head start” you keep bringing up is a complete nonfactor, because every team in the league is going to do their due diligence. Sitting on Carr for two weeks is going to accomplish absolutely nothing for the Raiders, because the supposed advantage other teams would have would result in absolutely nothing changing whatsoever besides a team *maybe* dropping out of the QB race earlier on, in which case the Raiders would get a draft pick for their troubles which is infinitely more valuable.

There is no “head start”. Every team that needs a QB is going to do their due diligence on every QB that’s available. That will not change if Carr is allowed to seek out a trade. That probably won’t change regardless of where Carr goes in the first place.

> Why would Carr want that? It's in Carrs best interest that his next team has more draft picks so they can surround him with more talent.

You keep arguing this point despite everyone agreeing with you. It makes all the sense I’m the world for Carr to not accept any trade. That doesn’t mean he wouldn’t. Dumb QB trades and dumb FA decisions can, have, and will happen.

> The Raiders are stupid sure, but it would be stupid to guarantee his 40m and try to seek out a non existent trade that cannot happen.

If a trade isn’t agreed to in principle by the 15th, Carr would be cut. Nobody is suggesting the Raiders would continue searching for a trade beyond this date. I’ve already said this.

> No, the supposed upside for the Raiders is non existent because he cannot get traded. Again, unless you think a team, Carr, and his agent are all stupid. It would hurt Carr and the team to trade for him. Why do you think. Carr got the no trade clause and the guarantees in February in the first place? It was either guarantee his contract or he becomes a free agent. Him/his agent wanted it structured that way.

Of course us almost certainly won’t happen. But that doesn’t mean it absolutely won’t. A stupid team could easily decide to pull the trigger, and maybe Carr is dumb enough to accept. Most likely not, but considering there’s literally zero upside to letting him waste away doing nothing before you cut him.

Give him a week and change to see if someone bites. If something works out, great! Free draft pick. If it doesn’t, oh well, you cut him on the 15th anyway. Nothing is lost.

50.author: fadingthought
50.body:
> To win 7 you have to be delivering. It doesn’t matter if you have the team of the century for 20 years straight you don’t win 7 if you aren’t good at qb

What I'm saying is the flip side is true as well. It doesn't matter how good your QB play is, if your defense lets you down you go home. If your special teams lets you down, you go home. Lots of QBs, great ones, have led the go ahead TD only to watch their defense crumble.  Plenty of mediocre QBs have won Super Bowls as well. Eli Manning is not better than Dan Marino. 

If Tom Brady was the king of playoff per game stats and he still won 7 rings then you could make the argument. You see it with Jordan because he won 6, but is the career PPG post season leader. He was the best player of the court for every single one of those post season championship and he played defense. 

Tom Brady wasn't. He's 20th in post season passer rating, right next to Joe Flacco and Joe Theismann. It goes both ways though too, because one of his most impressive playoff runs, he lost to the Eagles because the Patriots gave up 41 points. If they give up 31 Tom Brady has 8 SBs but is exactly the same QB. 

Tom Brady is great for a lot of reasons, but SB wins are a team stat. Unless you think Trent Dilfer is just as good as Aaron Rodgers and Terry Bradshaw is better than Drew Brees.

50.author: Kurchak_OW
50.body:
Some mediocre QB’s have won super bowls, but they almost never win multiple, certainly not 7. Dilfer had an insane defense. But again, I’m not saying winning as a subpar QB isn’t possible, just that you aren’t giving your team the best % chance of winning which you need if you win 7 SB’s, regardless of how good your team is. 


Tom is the goat but nowhere am I arguing that the Superbowls are the exclusive piece of evidence to support the conclusion. Does it help? It absolutely does, no idea why you aren’t giving it credit. The QB leads the team to victory, not just in the SB but throughout the season. That’s game in and game out impact - on the field and off it. 


Saying Brady could have won one more Super Bowl and been the same QB is very much different than comparing someone with 1 Super Bowl to 7. Come on. 


MJ was surrounded by an insane team which is ironic given that you discredit Brady for the same reason, but ok.PPG is a hard stat in a game with 5 v 5. It’s a pretty damn good method to measure impact. Is passer rating or QB rating? Absolutely not. Multiple people can score (running game), stats can get skewed, value can be lost in the formula, etc. 


For example, Brady could know exactly who to throw it to where to secure a first down in a crucial part of the game and not get additional credit in either formula. Know how to manage that drive to march the ball down with sufficient time to score but too little to give the other team much of a chance to counter, etc. that’s all intangible. You’ll never see this reflected on stat sheets it’s just immense game IQ that leads to wins, QB and Passer rating mean nothing. Some of the highest QBR games were pretty shit games. I’m the video game world we call it gamesense, Brady was the the best at it and it made the difference in winning games. NFL coaches call it “intangibles”, something they spend endless hours trying to spot in players. The NFL scouts are looking for something that you apparently don’t think exists because Passer Rating or QBR don’t support Brady winning 7 Super Bowls so it just have been him getting carried by the team. He just happened to luck into 7 SB wins and 10 appearances because of stacked teams, right. Teams equally stacked would be lucky to get 3 appearances in a generation. But you believe whatever you want.

50.author: fadingthought
50.body:
>Know how to manage that drive to march the ball down with sufficient time to score but too little to give the other team much of a chance to counter, etc. that’s all intangible.

My dude, do you listen to anything? Tom Brady doesn't play defense. In that AFC championship game I mentioned, Tom Brady scored the go ahead TD. His next two drives to end the game were 1 pass where he threw a pick and another one where he went 3 and out. 

How did his game sense and intangibles win that game? What about 2002 when the defense stopped the Titans and returned the punt into FG range for Vinitari? Or was his 1/4 passing for 4 yards key to winning that drive? Or 2015 when the Patriots stopped the Ravens from scoring the go ahead TD with a great interception? Tom Brady did that too? If Flacco scores there, is Brady worse? Is he worse if Ty Law doesn't get that pick-6 to beat the Rams? Cause Brady didn't score enough to win. 

MJ was surrounded by an insane team, but he was always the best player on the court and the box score showed it. Tom Brady has won more games playing worse than other greats won when they played great. 

All this isn't to say that Tom Brady isn't great, because he is. But a big reason he won was because he had an excellent team around him that came up big when they needed to. Coached by one of the all time great coaches who, by the way, has more SB wins than Brady. But SB wins are a team stat.

Like throwing a pick and going three and out but being bailed out by your defense. 

Literal next level plays. Highest statistical probability to win plays.

50.author: fadingthought
50.body: Yes, and career wise his stats are not as good as other players. He wins playing worse, statistically, than other QBs. Why? Because it’s a team game.

50.author: Kurchak_OW
50.body:
Stats class dude, please, for your own benefit. Like I’m not even trying to be a sarcastic ass. 


Completion percentage when Brady started was on average 10% lower than it is now. YPG 10% lower than it is now. TD/game 10% lower than it is now (most seasons). Interceptions 20% less are thrown now than 20 years ago. INT % down 30% now compared to then. QB rating 10-15% higher now compared to then. 


I can go on and on. So while you sit here saying he’s statistically not the best, while he’s statistically quite good. And you don’t bother to consider the evolution of the game and how his stats will be lower as EVERYONES stats were lower 10-20 years ago. Then you don’t consider that he played to 45 so stat averages wouldn’t be his strong suit as other QBs who retire 10 years earlier. Then you don’t consider any of the intangibles, leadership, pay cuts for better teams, etc. 


There’s nothing to really say. You’re looking at a current stat sheet, a single piece of paper, and trying to determine something without even analyzing the data. And ultimately the game is about winning which he did, and was massively impactful in doing so. Nobody is arguing it’s not a team sport but you’re the only one arguing he somehow stumbled into 7SBs while being the person who had his hand on the ball every damn play. 


According to your logic we have 3-4 NFL all time goat quarterbacks right now in the nfl, some of which have only been playing 2 or 3 seasons.

50.author: fadingthought
50.body:
You keep saying stats dude, which is ironic considering you keep bring up intangibles and leadership as a counter to stats. 

But you are right, passing has gotten easier over time partly due to rule changes over the years, most recently in 2009. So if we remove his early years and only look at the 2009 season to now, his passer rating goes up 1.3 points, he's still in 20th place but he is closer to Joe Theismann than he was before. 

But if we are going to era adjust for TB, we should also consider QBs who played their entire career in older eras and were close, but not higher than TB. Guys like Troy Aikman who was only 1.5 passer rating lower than Tom Brady and played in a harder era for QBs. 

Also guys like Bart Starr or Joe Montana who are way ahead of Tom Brady statistically and played in an harder era.  If we era adjust them, they get even further ahead of Tom Brady. 

You keep seeing to think I'm saying Tom Brady sucks and he stumbled into 7 SBs. Rather, I'm saying he is a HOF QB who was fortunate enough to play with good enough teams to win 7 SBs.

He doesn't have the individual accomplishments of someone like Gretzky to set his individual play so far apart from anyone else. In no other major sport do we consider the player with the most titles to be the best player. No one is arguing that Bill Russell is the best player of all time. Why? Because stats like this: There have been 12 seasons when a player was the scoring champ and the 1st team all defense. The one season Jerry West did it, the two times Kobe Bryant did it and the nine times Michael Jordan did it. Gretzky is the only player to have a 200 point season and he did it four times. 

Tom Brady's most impressive accomplishment is his longevity and his volume stats. He's a shoe in Hall of Famer, but he isn't the Gretzky of the NFL. He isn't the Jordan of the NFL. He's a great player who was lucky enough to be on a great team. Lots of great players, who played better, were not so lucky.

50.author: Kurchak_OW
50.body:
Because initially it was statistical chance of increasing win rate which you couldn’t understand so then you switched to hard average stats, which Ive already described cannot fully express the performance of a QB, then you also weren’t fair in going through those stats anyways. 


Link me where Brady is 20th in passer rating. Every site has him at 10, the NFL HOF website has him at 3. The sites with him in 10th show that every person above him played after him (usually starting their career within the last 6 years) and benefited from passer rating inflation (save maybe Brees). The only people even close to him on the list who started before he did are Steve Young and Peyton Manning, Brady is listed higher than them. Young retired at 38 and Manning at 39. 


So Brady has two other goat QB’s beat in all time passer rating while playing 6-7 years more post prime than they did. And not just regular post prime but 40+ year old post prime, where he also led his teams to 2 additional super bowls. 


If you’re gonna list your stats at least know what they are saying.

50.author: fadingthought
50.body:
https://www.pro-football-reference.com/leaders/pass_rating_career_playoffs.htm

Tom Brady is a great QB, no one is denying that. But his SB wins are team accomplishments and lots of people played better than him and lost. 

He doesn't have the individual accolades that sets him apart from his peers like people like Gretzky or MJ. The thing people default to is "Rings Ernie, Rings" People mock that in a sport where everyone plays both sides of the ball. Tom Brady doesn't play defense.

50.body: That’s QBR not PR, QBR is a notoriously crap stat tracker

51.author: owiseone23
51.body: I'm just saying we don't know either way. I don't think the metrics presented so far have been conclusive.

51.author: LeonidasSpacemanMD
51.body: They certainly lean way the hell in one direction lol

51.author: owiseone23
51.body:
Right, but they're expected to lean in that way for the reasons I mentioned. The question is how far they lean relative to expected.

Even assuming refs were 100% perfect, you'd expect Brady to be near the bottom of RTP calls and RTP/sack calls. I'm a mathematician, so maybe my threshold for evidence is higher, but I don't think just looking at those numbers is conclusive.

51.author: LeonidasSpacemanMD
51.body:
But I’ve already pointed out that even if a ridiculously high number of his RTP calls were suspect, it’s still an insanely low number of bad calls he’s benefitting from lol

Think about it this way: let’s say that Brady’s RTP calls are soft 25% of the time and Matt Ryan’s (another pocket passer whose been in the league for this entire span) are soft 10% of the time. We’re assuming Bradys getting 250% higher share of soft calls

That still amounts to 1 or 2 extra soft calls **TOTAL** over a 14 year span

You can do the same thing for Fitzpatrick, it comes out to about 3 more soft calls total, and Brady has played *over 100 more games* than Fitz lol

Honestly the more I look into this, it’s simply impossible to make a rational argument he gets favorable calls lol you have to assume that like 80% of his RTP calls are soft, at which point you run into the problem of how it’s even possible he’s only been legitimately roughed ~7 times when he has the most dropbacks of anyone

51.author: owiseone23
51.body:
The benefits aren't just those extra calls (if they exist) though. It affects how defenders try to tackle him. We saw in the Niners Cowboys game that Dak escaped a safety because the d lineman didn't want to blow him up and get a penalty. Brady's reputation for getting calls (whether true or not) may make defenders more cautious and gentle when trying to sack him.

To your last point, I don't think that would be crazy. He has great pocket awareness and goes down easy and is happy to throw the ball away. Also, he has one of the fastest releases in the game. So yeah, even though he has a lot of drawbacks, I don't think it'd be strange for him to have very few calls.

58.author: man2010
58.body: In other words, "I don't actually know that this technology exists, and despite the fact that the NFL says it isn't accurate within 6 inches I think throwing money at it can change that." Do you think the NFL can throw money at all its other problems to create technology out of thin air to address them?

58.author: SolarStarVanity
58.body:
NFL isn't sitting on it. Your question was "Do **we** have the technology?" which I took to mean, like, humanity. And yes, we do, it's called differential positioning. (A global version of that is called DGPS.) It gets more accurate with every transmitter (the analog of satellites in GPS), and the reality is that in an NFL stadium, you can place a shit ton of transmitters. (You couldn't use literal DGPS transmitters of course, but you get the idea, the math is the same.)

It's not the least costly solution to implement, but the technology very much exists, yes. The reality is though that NFL isn't particularly interested in the accuracy of games, they literally financially benefit from being able to control the outcome. Whether they make use of that benefit is another question that I don't know the answer to.

58.author: man2010
58.body: In other words, "this other technology that's used for other things exist, so in my armchair expert opinion it would work to track a football to the accuracy of a blade of grass at all times during a football game." You should get Goodell on the horn to sell this system to him since you're so sure it exists

64.author: FavreorFarva
64.body: Possibly, but it seemed our passing game worked better before the Dissly injury vs after to my eyes. I would definitely agree that it doesn’t make sense to routinely take one of DK and Lockett off the field but being able to effectively pass out of a heavy 3 TE set (that is almost certainly a run look to any defense) is a great wrinkle to have. I think 2 TEs set should be the norm but there is value to having 3 guys that are at minimum solid in both blocking and receiving.

64.author: IdMassageDeshaun
64.body: Yeah idk why our 3 TE set was so effective tbh. It was amazing to watch though. Dissly is such a beast when he’s healthy. I hope we keep all 3 but it might be hard.

64.author: FavreorFarva
64.body:
I honestly think it’s because it’s such a weird look in the modern NFL. Defenses are being built to stop 3-4 receiver sets and not get beat deep. As long as they can do those two things and not get run over in the run game a modern nfl defense seems to be in pretty good shape.

3 TE’a checks maybe one of those boxes, the run game. We aren’t going to try to hit a go route with 3 TEs usually, it’s more the intermediate stuff that TEs feast on, and we are making you very concerned about the run game because we have 8 big dudes on the field. 

Youre obviously gonna bring a safety down and play us in your base, but who covers who if you call man? The 3 TEs could see a CB, a S, or a LB depending on the matchup. If we know how to leverage those mismatches we can absolutely wreak havoc in the pass game on play action because we made the run your #1 problem with the formation. 

That’s my theory anyway. It’s the unfamiliarity of it and the way running out of that big personnel group dictates a defenses scheme and priorities. 

Would still rather do the same idea with two TEs so we can keep Lockett and DK on the field together too though. Not like DK can’t rag doll a CB if we choose to run his way anyway.

64.author: IdMassageDeshaun
64.body: Yeah definitely, it’s an issue for the defense cause our run game was great this year. But I think having only 2 TE makes them not have to fear the run as much. Idk it’s a weird position haha.
